name: Sri Lanka
summary: Ayubowan (ආයුබෝවන්) is a Sinhala greeting that means "May you live long".

all_steps.name: Dubai
all_steps.description:
We are off! 

Dubai is referred to as the Vegas of the Gulf, and I agree. It is too big, hot, and artificial for me. 

We had a blast at the waterpark. It was nice to recharge with some American foods and amenities.  One thing I loved about the city is what a melting pot of cultures were there. 80+% of the residents in Dubai are expats, so we saw people and foods from India, Pakistan, Asia, Africa, UK, etc.

all_steps.name: Sri Lanka
all_steps.description: We are in Sri Lanka! Ayubowan (ආයුබෝවන්) is a Sinhala greeting that means "May you live long". It is already so beautiful (and humid!). It is smaller than Utah and has 22 million people, Utah has 3 million!

all_steps.name: Sigiriya
all_steps.description:
After a long day of travel the kids had to get a swim in, even if it was late and dark. 

Our drive from the airport to the center of the country was CRAZY. This makes Greece, Italy, Paris, Greenland look like child’s play. There are scooters, tuk tuks, trucks, cars, buses, semis, all passing each other at the same time. And they drive on the left side. Thankful for our driver Mada for keeping us safe!

all_steps.name: Pidurangala Rock
all_steps.description:
To begin our awesome day, we hiked to Pidurangala Rock. It is a huge volcanic rock formation just north of the iconic UNESCO Lion’s Rock. At the base is an ancient Buddhist temple.

The views on top were amazing and we saw Gray Langur monkeys up close! A momma and two babies. On the drive, we saw a bunch of toque macaque and a land monitor.

If walking through Rome was like walking through a museum, walking through Sri Lanka is like walking through a zoo! We recorded 37 different species of animals today, and I know we missed a bunch. This place is amazing!

all_steps.name: Hiriwadunne Village Tour
all_steps.description:
Next we went on a village tour in Hiriwadunne. It is a small village that has a lot of traditions and culture of rural Sri Lanka.

First, we went on a bullock cart ride through the rice paddies. We also so the tree houses that the farmer sleeps in to help keep animals out of the crops. The male cows have a big hump on their back that helps yoke them together to pull the cart. The driver walks beside them giving them calls and commands.

Next we went on a catamaran boat ride through the lake. There were saw fish (and villagers fishing with their stick poles), lots of birds, and beautiful views of Sigiriya and Pidurangala rocks. Our boatmen made us hats out of lily pads!

Then we had lunch at a villagers house. We ate rice and curry on banana leaves with our hands. Then she showed us how she to make a roof out of coconut leaves and how to use kulla and mirisgala to separate rice seeds from the husks and straw. This was a true farm to table culinary experience.

We heard music as we were finishing up that sounded like an ice cream truck, but it actually was a tuk tuk selling bread!

We got to take our first tuk tuk ride to our next stop.

all_steps.name: Safari at Hurulu Eco Park
all_steps.description:
Wow! What an amazing experience. We saw so much wildlife on this safari. Of course the highlight was getting up close to 5 different herds of elephants - probably about 50-60, and the cutest little babies!!

But we also loved the birds and small animals. We had the best jeep driver that knew where to go and respect the animals too!

I was sad that I didn’t have my big nice camera with telephoto lens with me (it didn’t make the packing list), but there was no need for it with the elephants, they were so close! It still would have been nice with the birds though.

Fran was in animal heaven. We all were. Today may have made all the challenges of travel, being away from home, and all of that a little bit better.

all_steps.name: Pool, birds, and curry
all_steps.description:
We finished the day off bird watching from the pool (they get more active in the evenings and mornings). And more delicious Sri Lankan curry!

Video of our day from our driver and amazing tour guide Mada!

all_steps.name: Dumballa Cave Temple
all_steps.description: This morning we visited the Buddhist Dumbulla Cave temple. It had five rooms with ancient frescos and lots of different Buddha statues in a variety of poses. It was fascinating to learn more about Buddhism.

all_steps.name: Pitawala pathana
all_steps.description: Next we drove on narrow, windy, potholed filled roads to the Knuckles Conservation Forest. The mountains here are gorgeous. We did a short hike to the “mini worlds end” with amazing views. Then we were able to get some homework done as we watched the storm come in.

all_steps.name: Manigala Ridge
all_steps.description:
Today we did the approximately 8km round trip hike to Maningala Ridge. Don’t let the distance fool you, like it did us, we were sweating buckets in the humidity and ~500m elevation gain.

We were told we would have a tracker with us, I was expecting a Garmin Spot, or something similar. It turns out to be a local villager in flip flops, a plastic grocery sack with a water bottle, that doesn’t talk much.

It was a terrific hike that started by going past the rice paddy’s and agricultural fields to a gorgeous overlook of the Knuckles Mountains.

Fran’s highlight of the hike was the 20+ village dogs that took turns escorting us along the trail. A low light was the leeches we acquired along the way.

all_steps.name: Kandy
all_steps.description: So our hotel has monkeys at our balcony and the best view at the pool. Wow!

all_steps.name: Cultural Dance Show
all_steps.description: Our guide took us to a dance show that showcased some of theof the cultural dances and clothing from around Sri Lanka. Including a fire dance!

location.name: Slightly Chilled Lounge Bar and Restaurant

all_steps.name: Kandy Sacred Temple of the Tooth
all_steps.display_name: Kandy Sacred Temple of the Tooth
all_steps.description: We then went to the most sacred and special site for Buddhist in Sri Lanka. This temple houses the famous relic of the Buddha's tooth transported to Sri Lanka from India in the 4th century. There we were able to bring a flower offering to Buddha and see the chamber that holds the relic.

all_steps.name: Tea Plantation and Factory
all_steps.description:
Sri Lanka’s largest export is tea. The humidity, cool temperatures, and rainfall of the country's central highlands provide a climate that favors the production of high-quality tea. We learned about how tea is hand picked. The end three leaves are picked, and 7 days later new ones have grown and they are ready to be picked again. From these three leaves four different teas are produced:
   First leaf = white tea
   First and second ‎ =  green
   Third = golden
   All three = black

We were shown the process to wash, dry, chop, sieve and sort the leaves. Then tasted the four types. White was by far the best.

I thought a lot today about modern day slavery. Tea was introduced to the country by the British when under colonial rule m. To help work the fields Tamils were brought over from India in the 19th century. These people are still same of the most disadvantaged in the country and face many hardships, with no power. Of course this wasn’t brought up in our tour. Read more here: https://www.aisls.org/resources/teaching-about-sri-lanka/teaching-about-tea/tea-and-immigrant-labor/

all_steps.name: Nine Arch Bridge
all_steps.description:
One of the lasting benefits from the colonial period is the trains system. We visited the iconic nine arch bridge. This bridge is an engineering marvel. The construction faced significant logistical challenges, including difficult terrain and material transport. It took 8 years to build and was complete in 1929.

Today, the trains were not running in this area due to filming of an Indian movie. The filming is taking place for six days. We were going to ride an earlier segment of the train, but due to the spontaneity of this trip would only be able to get standing tickets. We weren’t very excited about standing in a crowded and cramped train for hours, despite the beautiful scenery and appeal of train travel.

all_steps.name: Driving through Sri Lanka
all_steps.description:
We drove 689 km across Sri Lanka in 6 days with our incredible driver Mada.

It was exhausting, these Sri Lankan roads are nothing to joke about. The two lane roads are lined with families stands selling their home grown bananas, vegetables, strawberries, curd, flowers, or whatever else. There are countless number of village dogs walking along the road, or laying in the road. One day, Fran counted 78 dog’s in about 1.5 hours of driving. Also, watch out for wildlife. We saw giant snails, monkeys, lizards, elephants, land monitors, mongoose and peacocks. Then there is the livestock: cows, buffalo, chickens, or goats. You have small trucks or tuk tuks loaded up with produce, or sugar cane, or lots of people. Or they take up a whole lane of the road to dry rice. In the cities, you have the school kids walking home from school in their white uniforms. You have shops and temples along the side of the road.

You have people walking, carts, bikes, scooters, tuk tuks, cars, trucks, and buses. Everyone trying to pass everyone else, and no one stop for anybody. Oh, and to intensify this craziness, it is right hand drive.

This video is speed up and through a small town, so very little going on.

BUT… the scenery was gorgeous! The mountains and trees. The buffalos grazing with the egrets. I loved the rice paddy’s and the tea plantations terraced into the hills. Or in one area, there were vegetable paddy’s terraced into every available space - families trying to make a living.

all_steps.name: Kamburugamuwa
all_steps.description: We reached our beach house! This will be home for the next week or more. We are excited to be done driving and moving around. And the WiFi is fast and stable!!! It is the upstairs apartment of the nicest owners, not too far from the ocean, and it has a nice small pool!

all_steps.name: Surf Lessons - Weligama
all_steps.description: Today we had surf lessons in Weligama! We started off on the beach learning proper technique. Then we went out. Our instructor would give our board an extra push and tell us when to paddle and stand. We all were successful a few times riding the wave in! Fran did the best because with her light weight, she was able to stay balanced. It is hard to get all of the pieces right. It has been super rainy here in the south coast, so although it was still raining, I’m glad we were able to get out.

all_steps.name: More Surfing!
all_steps.description: More surfing today! We switched to a different surf school and had an even better experience for half the price. We learned so much. It is hard, and I feel drowned by salt water, but we keep getting better! Fran is a pro they say, keep her going!

all_steps.name: Weligama Bay
all_steps.description: More surfing! We really rocked it today. We rode lots of waves! Our instructors have been awesome! Tomorrow we learn to turn.

all_steps.name: Madiha Beach
all_steps.description:
We took a tuk tuk to a near by beach for dinner. Dinner was great and we had a nice view of the ocean where the waves were huge and crazy. Then we saw a beautiful sunset! We were also treated to some peacocks and a peahen.

We then walked to the grocery store for some supplies and survived our walk home on the crazy road!

all_steps.name: Learning to turn
all_steps.description:
Today we learned to turn. Our instructors were impressed that both Harvey and I could turn both directions on our first day. Thank you snowboarding and skate/long boarding!

Then we piled 6 into our tuk tuk to drive back! Party in the Tuk Tuk!!

all_steps.name: Last Surf Lesson
all_steps.description:
Today we had our last surf lesson. We are all consistently getting up and turning. Harvey and I were also catching waves on our own. Dila was a great instructor! We had so much fun and can’t wait to go have another surf holiday!

See the full surf video on youtube: https://youtu.be/LOleZ_PGxh8

all_steps.name: Goodbye Sri Lanka
all_steps.description:
After our last surf lesson, we hired a driver to take us to a hotel near the airport. While waiting for dinner (these hotel restaurants always serve dinner much later than we like!!) we played in the garden where we saw huge bats fly across the sky. It was so cool!

Sri Lanka was amazing! We would love to come back! The wildlife and nature where phenomenal. The landscape, culture, and people where beautiful. We LOVED surfing. But getting was hard, and finding food on our own was hard.
